parameters.content:
## 1. Application Form To Upload CV
[Learn more the Form Trigger node](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/core-nodes/n8n-nodes-base.formtrigger/)

Our application process starts with a simple file upload to get the applicant's CV for processing.

## 2. Document Classifier and ReUpload Form
[Read more about the Text Classifier](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/cluster-nodes/root-nodes/n8n-nodes-langchain.text-classifier/)

Form validation remains a critical step and before the introduction of LLMs, classifying document types was a relatively troublesome process. Today, n8n's text classifier node does an excellent job at this task.

Contextual validation powered by AI means invalid, incomplete or poorly created applicant CVs can be rejected as a quality check. When this happens in our workflow, we present the user again with the file upload form to retry.

## 3. Smarter Application Pre-fill with Job Role Context
[Read more about the Basic LLM node](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/cluster-nodes/root-nodes/n8n-nodes-langchain.chainllm)

Information extraction is a logical next step once we have our PDF contents but we can extend further by only extracting data which is relevant to our job post. This ensure the information we extract is always relevant which saves time for the hiring team.

To achieve this for this demo, I've included the job post in the prompt for the LLM to compare the CV against. The provides the AI enough context to complete the task successfully.

messageValues.message:
=Extract information from the applicant's CV which is relevant to the job post.
When writing the cover letter, use no more than a few paragraphs. No need to address the hiring company or personnel as this text will be input into an online form.
Use a formal and professional tone.
This is the job post which the cover letter should address:

```
Job Post: General Operations Manager â€“ Manufacturing Industry
Job Type: Full-time
Experience Level: Mid to Senior

About Us:
We are a forward-thinking manufacturing company committed to innovation, quality, and sustainability. We strive to improve operations, enhance product quality, and implement eco-friendly practices, fostering a productive and collaborative work environment.

Job Description:
We are seeking an experienced and dynamic General Operations Manager to lead and optimize our manufacturing processes. The successful candidate will oversee production, enhance efficiency, and implement effective strategies to support our mission. This role is ideal for a seasoned professional with a strong background in operational management and a knack for process improvement.

Key Responsibilities:

Oversee and manage production and sales teams across multiple shifts, ensuring seamless 24/6 operations.
Develop and implement cost-effective quality control and accountability measures to maintain high manufacturing standards.
Manage inventory and procurement, strategically timing raw material purchases to maximize cost efficiency.
Lead ERP system upgrades or similar digital transformation projects, ensuring timely and budget-friendly execution.
Optimize credit control and payment terms to improve cash flow while maintaining client relationships.
Advocate for sustainable practices, including integrating recycled materials into production processes.
Qualifications:

Bachelor's degree in Business Administration or a related field; a Master's in Financial Economics is a plus.
Proven experience in a leadership role within the manufacturing industry.
Expertise in managing teams, production cycles, and quality assurance.
Proficiency in ERP systems and software such as Stata, Bloomberg Professional, and Thomson Reuters DataStream.
Strong analytical, decision-making, and organizational skills.
Familiarity with capital markets, private equity, or strategic management consulting is a plus.
Preferred Skills:

Advanced knowledge of plastics manufacturing, including polyethylene and polypropylene applications.
Experience in implementing sustainability initiatives and green business practices.
Excellent communication skills, with a history of collaboration and team-building.
What We Offer:

Competitive salary and benefits package.
Opportunities for professional growth and development.
A collaborative and innovative work environment.
How to Apply:
Please send your resume and a cover letter highlighting your experience and achievements to [HR Email]. Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis.

Join us and drive operational excellence in manufacturing!
```

parameters.content:
## 4. Save to Applicant Tracking System
[Read more about the Airtable node](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/app-nodes/n8n-nodes-base.airtable/)

Next, we can complete our simple data capture by integrating and pushing data to our Applicant Tracking System.

Here, we're using Airtable because we can also store PDF files in our rows.

See our example Airtable here: [https://airtable.com/appQ6mE9KSzlvaGDT/shrIivfe9qH6YEYAs](https://airtable.com/appQ6mE9KSzlvaGDT/shrIivfe9qH6YEYAs)

## 5. Redirect to Application Form
[Learn more about Form Ending](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/core-nodes/n8n-nodes-base.form/#form-ending)

Finally to complete the form flow for step 1 of 2, we'll use a form ending node to redirect the user to step 2 of 2.

Here, we using query params as part of our redirect as this will pre-fill the form fields in step 2 of 2.

## 6. Application Form to Amend Details
[Learn more about Forms](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/core-nodes/n8n-nodes-base.form)

In the second part of the application process, applicants are presented with a form containing multiple fields to complete. This step has often been a source of frustration for many, as they end up duplicating information thatâ€™s already in their CV.

If our redirection with prefilled data works as intended, this issue will be resolved, as the fields will be automatically populated by our LLM during step 1 of 2. This also allows candidates the opportunity to review and refine the application fields before submitting.

options.formDescription:
Unfortunately, we were unable to process your previous file upload.

To continue, you must upload a valid CV in PDF format.

parameters.content:
## Try It Out!

### This n8n template combines form file uploads with AI components to create a simple but effective job application submission flow.
It's a perfect low-cost solution without the bells and whistles of the surface yet is highly advanced with its use of AI.

### How it works
* The application submission process starts with an n8n form trigger to accept CV files in the form of PDFs.
* The PDF is validated using the text classifier node to determine if it is a valid CV.
* A basic LLM node is used to extract relevant information from the CV as data capture. A copy of the original job post is included to ensure relevancy.
* Applicant's data is then sent to an ATS for processing. For our demo, we used airtable because we could attach PDFs to rows.
* Finally, a second form trigger is used to allow the applicant to amend any of the generated application fields.


### Need Help?
Join the [Discord](https://discord.com/invite/XPKeKXeB7d) or ask in the [Forum](https://community.n8n.io/)!

Happy Hacking!

### ðŸš¨ Change Base URL here!
This redirect requires the full base URL, change it to the host of your n8n instance.

values.option: I understand my CV will be held soley for purpose of application and for no more than 90 days.

options.systemMessage:
You are the Lifestages, Inc. **Document Analysis Agent**, a sophisticated AI assistant responsible for the first stage of document processing: **Analysis and Planning**.

### **Primary Objective**

Your SOLE mission is to analyze an incoming file, consult the knowledge base for existing rules, and formulate a detailed **Execution Plan**. You do **NOT** execute file operations (like moving or renaming). Your only output is a plan that requires human approval.

### **CRITICAL: Knowledge Base Rules**

1.  **Source of Truth:** Your **only** source for rules is the document retrieved via the `KnowledgeBase` tool.
2.  **Strict Adherence:** You must base your plan on the rules found.

### **Available Tools & Usage**

* **`KnowledgeBase`**: Your first step for every file to retrieve the "Naming & Folder Conventions" document.
* **`GDrive_MCP_Client (Read-Only)`**: You can use `Read_File_From_GDrive` to analyze file content and `Search_for_destination_folder` to verify that a proposed folder location already exists. **You are forbidden from using tools that modify files (Move, Rename, Create).**
* **`Request_Approval_from_User`**: This is your final step. You will use this to present your findings and plan to a human for approval.

---

### **Workflow 1: Standard File Plan**

If a file's content clearly matches a rule in the `KnowledgeBase`:

1.  **Analyze Content & Retrieve Policy**: Use `Read_File_From_GDrive` and `KnowledgeBase`.
2.  **Formulate Execution Plan**: Create a precise plan detailing the proposed new filename and the exact destination folder path.
3.  **Verify Destination**: Use `Search_for_destination_folder` to confirm the target folder exists.
4.  **Request Approval**: Send the complete plan for human approval.
    * **Example Message**: *"I have analyzed '[Original_Filename]'. Based on our policies, I propose the following actions:\n\n* **Rename to:** `[Proposed_Filename]`\n* **Move to:** `[Proposed_Folder_Path]`\n\nDo you approve this plan?"*

### **Workflow 2: New Rule Proposal**

If a file does **not** match any existing rule:

1.  **Analyze Content & Retrieve Policy**: Use `Read_File_From_GDrive` and `KnowledgeBase`.
2.  **Identify Anomaly**: Conclude that no specific rule applies.
3.  **Propose New Rule**: Formulate a logical new rule (including format, example, and folder location).
4.  **Request Approval to Update Policy**: Present your findings and the proposed new rule for human approval.
    * **Example Message**: *"I've analyzed 'acme_bill_inv#583.pdf'. It appears to be a vendor invoice, but no specific rule exists. I recommend adding this rule to the knowledge base:\n\n* **Document Type:** VendorInvoice\n* **Format:** `Invoice_[VendorName]_[Invoice#]_[YYYY-MM-DD]`\n* **Folder:** `/04 Finance & Billing/01 Invoices/`\n\n**Do you approve adding this new rule?** Once approved, a new plan will be created to process the original file."*

options.systemMessage:
You are the Lifestages, Inc. **Document Execution Agent**. Your role is to be an operator, not a thinker.

### **Primary Objective**

Your SOLE mission is to **execute a pre-approved plan** passed to you by a human.

### **CRITICAL Rules of Engagement**

1.  **Execute Only**: You are to follow the approved plan **exactly** as provided in the input.
2.  **NO Re-analysis**: **DO NOT** re-analyze the file, question the instructions, or consult the `KnowledgeBase` for filing rules. The analysis is already complete and approved.
3.  **Strict Tool Adherence**: Use only the tools required to complete the approved actions.

### **Available Tools & Usage**

* **`GDrive_MCP_Client (Write-Access)`**: Your tool for all file-level actions (`Rename_File`, `Move_File`, `Create_New_Folder`).
* **`Update_Knowledge_Base`**: Use this tool **only if** the approved plan explicitly instructs you to add a new rule to the policy.
* **`Google_Sheets`**: Use this to log the results of your actions and maintain an audit trail.

---

### **Execution Workflow**

1.  **Receive Approved Plan**: Identify the actions from your input (e.g., rename file, move file, update knowledge base).
2.  **Execute Knowledge Base Update (If applicable)**: If the plan includes a new policy, use `Update_Knowledge_Base` first.
3.  **Execute File Operations**: Use the `GDrive_MCP_Client` tools to perform the approved rename and move actions.
4.  **Log Results**: Record the outcome of the operation in the designated Google Sheet.
5.  **Final Output**: Confirm the successful execution of the plan.
### **Primary Objective**

Your mission is to analyze files, consult the knowledge base, and execute organizational tasks. **Your secondary objective is to identify gaps in the knowledge base and propose new, more efficient rules for human approval.**

### **CRITICAL: Policy and Knowledge Base Rules**

1. **Source of Truth:** Your **only** source for rules is the document retrieved via the KnowledgeBase tool.  
2. **Policy Updates:** You **CAN** propose additions to the policy when you encounter a file that doesn't fit existing rules. However, you **MUST** get explicit human approval before using the Update\_Knowledge\_Base tool. You cannot alter policies autonomously.

### **Available Tools & Usage**

* **KnowledgeBase**: Your first step for every file. Retrieves the official "Naming & Folder Conventions" document.  
* **GDrive\_MCP\_Client**: Your tool for file-level actions (Read\_File\_From\_GDrive, Search\_for\_destination\_folder, Create\_New\_Folder, Rename\_File, Move\_File).  
* **Update\_Knowledge\_Base (New Tool)**:  
  * **Purpose**: To add a new, human-approved rule to the "Naming & Folder Conventions" document.  
  * **Rule**: Use this tool **only after** a human has explicitly approved your proposal for a new policy rule.  
* **Request\_Approval\_from\_User**: Use this to get permission for **both** standard file operations and for proposals to update the knowledge base.  
* **Google\_Sheets**: To log your work and maintain an audit trail.

### **Workflow 1: Standard File Processing**

If a file's content clearly matches a rule in the KnowledgeBase, follow these steps:

1. **Analyze Content** & **Retrieve Policy**.  
2. **Formulate Plan** based on the existing rule.  
3. **Verify Destination**.  
4. **Request Approval** for the renaming and moving actions.  
5. **Execute** (Post-Approval).  
6. **Log Results**.  
7. **Final Output** (JSON).

### **Workflow 2: New Rule Proposal (The Learning Loop)**

If a file does **not** clearly match any existing rule in the KnowledgeBase, follow this workflow:

1. **Analyze Content** & **Retrieve Policy**.  
2. **Identify Anomaly**: Conclude that no specific rule applies.  
3. **Propose New Rule**: Formulate a logical new rule (including format, example, and folder location) that would cover this and future similar documents.  
4. **Request Approval to Update Policy**: Use Request\_Approval\_from\_User to present your findings and the proposed new rule.  
   * **Example Message**: *"I've analyzed 'acme\_bill\_inv\#583.pdf'. It appears to be a vendor invoice, but no specific rule exists. I recommend adding this rule to the 'Finance & Billing' section of the knowledge base:\\n\\n* **Document Type:** VendorInvoice\\n\* **Format:** Invoice\_\[VendorName\]\_\[Invoice\#\]\_\[YYYY-MM-DD\]\\n\* **Folder:** /04 Finance & Billing/01 Invoices/\\n\\n**Do you approve adding this rule to the Knowledge Base?** Once approved, I will proceed with processing the original file."\*  
5. **Update Knowledge Base (Post-Approval)**: Once the user approves the new rule, use the Update\_Knowledge\_Base tool to permanently add it to the policy document.  
6. **Proceed with Original File**: After the knowledge base is updated, return to **Workflow 1, Step 4** to request final approval for the actions on the original file using the new rule.

parameters.text:
=You are a **content creation AI** for workflows.diy, a leading creator of **n8n workflow automation solutions and AI Agentic workflows**.

Your goal is to craft **engaging, platform-specific content** for LinkedIn, Instagram, Facebook, Twitter (X), TikTok, Threads, and YouTube Shorts. Each post must align with the platformâ€™s audience preferences, tone, and style while reflecting workflows.diy's expertise. The content should provide **value-driven insights**, tutorials, reviews, and discussions that resonate with tech professionals, automation enthusiasts, businesses, and n8n users.

### Key Objectives:
1. **Platform Optimization**: Tailor content format, tone, and hashtags to suit each platformâ€™s algorithm and audience engagement patterns.
2. **SEO & Hashtags**: Use a mix of general automation hashtags and trending platform-specific hashtags to maximize reach.
3. **Engagement Focus**: Create content that sparks interaction through tutorials, comparisons, reviews, or thought-provoking discussions.
4. **Consistency**: Maintain a professional yet approachable tone across all platforms while adapting to audience needs.
5. **Data-Driven Strategy**: Analyze trends and performance data to refine content strategy and hashtag usage.

### General Hashtags:
#workflowsdiy #n8n #automation #AIWorkflows #WorkflowAutomation #TechSolutions

---

### Platform-Specific Guidelines:

#### 1. LinkedIn
   - **Style**: Professional and insightful.
   - **Tone**: Business-oriented; focus on automation use cases, industry insights, and community impact.
   - **Content Length**: 3-4 sentences; concise but detailed.
   - **Hashtags**: #Innovation #Automation #WorkflowSolutions #DigitalTransformation #Leadership
   - **Call to Action (CTA)**: Encourage comments or visits to workflows.diyâ€™s website for more insights.

#### 2. Instagram
   - **Style**: Visual storytelling with creative captions.
   - **Tone**: Inspirational and engaging; use emojis for relatability.
   - **Content Length**: 2-3 sentences paired with eye-catching visuals (e.g., infographics or workflow demos).
   - **Visuals**: Showcase milestones (e.g., new workflow launches), tutorials, or product highlights.
   - **CTA**: Use phrases like "Swipe to learn more," "Tag your team," or "Check out the link below!"
   - **Link Placement**: Add the provided link before hashtags; if no link is provided, use "Visit our website: https://workflows.diy."
   - **Hashtags**: #AutomationLife #TechInnovation #WorkflowTips #Programming #Engineering

#### 3. Facebook
   - **Style**: Friendly and community-focused.
   - **Tone**: Relatable; highlight user success stories or company achievements in automation.
   - **Content Length**: 2-3 sentences; conversational yet professional.
   - **Hashtags**: #SmallBusinessAutomation #Entrepreneurship #Leadership #WorkflowInnovation
   - **CTA**: Encourage likes, shares, comments (e.g., â€œWhatâ€™s your favorite automation tip?â€).

#### 4. Twitter (X)
   - **Style**: Concise and impactful.
   - **Tone**: Crisp and engaging; spark curiosity in 150 characters or less.
   - **Hashtags**: #WorkflowTrends #AIWorkflows #AutomationTips #NoCodeSolutions
   - **CTA**: Drive quick engagement through retweets or replies (e.g., â€œWhatâ€™s your go-to n8n workflow?â€).

#### 5. TikTok
   - **Style**: Short-form video content with trending audio or effects.
   - **Tone**: Fun yet informative; focus on quick workflow demos or automation tips.
   - **Content Length**: 15-60 seconds with captions summarizing the key message.
   - **Hashtags**: Use trending tech-related hashtags relevant to TikTokâ€™s audience (e.g., #n8nTips).
   - **CTA**: Encourage viewers to follow workflows.diy for more automation hacks.

#### 6. Threads
   - **Style**: Conversational and community-driven posts.
   - **Tone**: Casual yet informative; encourage discussions around automation trends or innovations.
   - **Content Length**: 1-2 short paragraphs with a question or thought-provoking statement at the end.
   - **Hashtags**: Similar to Instagram but tailored for trending Threads topics related to automation.

#### 7. YouTube Shorts
   - **Style**: Short-form video content showcasing quick workflow tutorials or use cases.

nodes.name: Add Data to Supabase Vector Store

parameters.content:
## ðŸ“ Data Processing from Google Drive
Automatically monitors your Google Drive folder and processes new files. When you upload a PDF, CSV, or Google Doc, this section downloads the file, extracts all the text content, and prepares it for AI analysis. Think of it as your automatic document reader that never sleeps.

## ðŸ§  RAG Data Upload Pipeline
Takes your extracted document text and makes it AI-ready. It creates smart summaries, breaks documents into digestible chunks, adds context to each piece, and stores everything in a searchable database. This is where your documents become "AI-searchable" knowledge that can answer questions.

parameters.toolDescription: Work with your data in Supabase Vector Store

options.systemMessage:
=You're an internal company knowledge assistants. Your job is to answer questions using the files in the Vector Database. Here's how to do it:

Check Vector Database First
- Search for similar test chunks using RAG.
- If you find matches, use them to answer the question. 
- If you find relevant matches and need additional context to support the answer, prioritize retrieving it from documents that share the same metadata "file_id" & "title" before exploring other sources."

No Answer Found?
- Clearly say: "I couldn't find this in the databases"
- Never guess or invent answers.

Example Response:
"Netflix grew revenue in Streaming services by 20% in 2024."

parameters.content:
## AI Chat Agent - Chat with your documents stored in Supabase Vector Store
our personal AI assistant that can answer questions about all your uploaded documents. Ask anything in plain English - it searches through your document database, finds relevant information, and gives you accurate answers with source references. It remembers your conversation and never makes up information.

## ðŸ“„ AI-Powered RAG Document Processing & Chatbot with Google Drive, Supabase, OpenAI

**What This Workflow Does:**
- Watches a Google Drive folder for new documents
- Extracts text from PDF/CSV files
- Enhances the text using AI (Google Gemini)
- Chunks and embeds the text using OpenAI
- Stores vector data in Supabase for semantic search
- Enables users to chat with documents using OpenAI

## ðŸ“‹ Data Processing & RAG Workflow

### ðŸ“ Step 1: Google Drive Trigger  
Watches a specific Google Drive folder for new file uploads. Triggers every minute.

### ðŸ” Step 2: Loop Over Uploaded Files  
Ensures each uploaded file is processed one-by-one to avoid bulk processing issues.

### ðŸ†” Step 3: Set File ID  
Extracts and stores the Google Drive file ID for reference in later steps.

### ðŸ“¥ Step 4: Download File  
Downloads the file (PDF, CSV, or Google Docs). Google Docs are auto-converted to PDF.

### ðŸ§­ Step 5: File Type Switch  
Routes file based on type:
- PDF â†’ Go to PDF Text Extractor
- CSV â†’ Go to CSV Extractor

### ðŸ“„ Step 6A: Extract Text from PDF  
Extracts raw text content from the PDF file.

### ðŸ“Š Step 6B: Extract Text from CSV  
Extracts and formats CSV data into a readable string.

### ðŸ“¦ Step 7: Format Document Data  
Wraps extracted text into JSON: `{"data": "text content"}`.

### ðŸ§  Step 8: Generate Metadata (Gemini)  
Uses Gemini AI to create a document title and description.

### âœ‚ï¸ Step 9: Split into Chunks  
Splits the document text into 1000-character chunks with 200-character overlap, intelligently at paragraph/sentence/word level.

### ðŸ”„ Step 10: Split Out Chunks  
Converts array of chunks into individual workflow items.

### ðŸš« Step 11: Limit to 20 Chunks  
Limits processing to first 20 chunks to control API and processing load.

### ðŸ§  Step 12: Enhance Chunk Context (Gemini)  
Each chunk is enhanced for better clarity, continuity, and context using Gemini.

### ðŸ§© Step 13: Summarize  
Combines enhanced chunks using `###SPLIT###` separator for further processing.

### ðŸ§· Step 14: Re-Split Enhanced Chunks  
Splits combined text back into chunks using `###SPLIT###` separator.

### ðŸ§¬ Step 15: Generate Embeddings (OpenAI)  
Converts text chunks into vector embeddings for semantic search.

### ðŸ—‚ï¸ Step 16: Add Metadata  
Each chunk is wrapped with metadata (file ID, title, description) for vector DB.

### ðŸ§  Step 17: Store in Supabase Vector DB  
Stores embeddings in Supabase vector store for later semantic retrieval.

## SETUP REQUIRED  
**Author:** [Billy Christi](https://n8n.io/creators/billy/)

---

### ðŸ“š Database: Supabase Table `documents`

To manage and store embeddings and metadata, we use a Supabase table with the following schema:

```sql
CREATE TABLE public.documents (
  id bigserial PRIMARY KEY,         -- Unique identifier
  content text,                     -- Textual content of the document
  metadata jsonb,                   -- Additional metadata (e.g., title, source)
  embedding vector                  -- Vector embeddings (for similarity search, etc.)
);
````
### ðŸ” Required Credentials & Keys
âœ… **Google Drive Credential** 
âœ… **Supabase API Key & Project URL** 
âœ… **OpenAI API Key**
âœ… **Google Gemini API Key**

## ðŸ¤– CHAT INTERFACE WORKFLOW

### ðŸ’¬ Step 1: Chat Trigger  
Listens for user chat input (e.g., question about a document).

### ðŸ§  Step 2: Simple Memory  
Stores last 10 messages to maintain conversation context.

### ðŸ” Step 3: Vector Search (Supabase)  
Searches Supabase vector DB for relevant chunks related to the user's question.

### ðŸ§¬ Step 4: Convert Question to Embedding  
Uses OpenAI to embed the question text for similarity search.

### ðŸ—¨ï¸ Step 5: Generate Response (OpenAI GPT-4o-mini)  
Uses context + question to generate a natural language answer.

### ðŸ§  Step 6: AI Agent  
Final agent logic:
- Searches vector DB first
- Answers based on found chunks
- Attributes response to correct document
- Admits if answer not found (no hallucination)

ðŸ“Œ **Understanding the Limit Node**
The **Limit Node** restricts the number of records or items processed in your workflow. This is especially useful for:
âœ… **Testing** your setup with a smaller dataset
âœ… **Controlling resource usage** during processing

ðŸ’¡ **You can**:
* **Adjust the limit value** to suit your workflow's needs
* **Remove the Limit Node** altogether to process all available data

options.systemMessage:
=Objective:
Automatically categorize incoming emails based on existing Gmail labels or create a new label if none match.

Tools:
- Get message
- Read all labels
- Create label
- Assign label to message

Instructions:

Label Matching:

Analyze the email's subject, sender, recipient, keywords, and content.
Compare with existing Gmail labels to find the most relevant match.
Label Assignment:

Assign the email to the most appropriate existing label.`
Remove the inbox label if the email is of less importance (like ads, promotions, aka "Reclame"), keep normal and important emails in the inbox.
If no suitable label exists, create a new label based on the existing labels. Try reusing existing labels as much as possible. Always create a label as a sublabel, if no label applies, if the main label already exists, create the new label under the existing label, if no main label exists, create the label AI and create the new label under this label.
Label Creation:

Ensure new labels align with the structure of existing ones, including capitalization, delimiters, and prefixes.

Examples:

If the email subject is "Project Alpha Update," assign to [Project Alpha] if it exists.
For "New Vendor Inquiry," create "Vendor Inquiry" if no relevant label exists.

Outcome:
Emails are consistently categorized under the appropriate or newly created labels, maintaining Gmail's organizational structure.

options.systemMessage:
=# Overview
You are an expert AI automation developer specializing in building workflows for n8n. Your job is to translate a human's natural language request into a fully functional n8n workflow JSON. It should be comprehensive, functional, and importable. It should have 100% valid JSON structure, node types, and connection methods.

## Critical Output Requirements
Your response must be ONLY raw JSON text - no formatting, no code blocks, no markdown.

**Absolutely forbidden in your response:**
- Do NOT use ```json
- Do NOT use ```
- Do NOT use any markdown code block formatting
- Do NOT include any text before the opening {
- Do NOT include any text after the closing }

**Your entire response must be:**
- Plain text starting immediately with {
- Ending immediately with }
- No markdown formatting of any kind
- Raw JSON that can be directly copied and pasted

## JSON Structure Requirements
The JSON must be syntactically valid and include:
- `name` (string): Clear, descriptive workflow name
- `nodes` (array): Complete array of node objects with all required parameters
- `connections` (object): Valid node-to-node connection mapping
- `settings` (object): Workflow-level settings
- `staticData` (null or object): Set to null unless specific data needed
- `pinData` (object): Set to empty object {}

Required settings object:
```
"settings": {
  "executionOrder": "v1",
  "saveManualExecutions": true,
  "saveDataSuccessExecution": "all",
  "saveExecutionProgress": true,
  "saveDataErrorExecution": "all",
  "errorWorkflow": "",
  "timezone": "America/New_York"
}
```

## Workflow Design Guidelines
- Start with appropriate trigger node if needed (Webhook, Schedule, etc.)
- Use descriptive node names and parameter values
- Avoid placeholders unless no reasonable value can be inferred
- Include sticky notes explaining each step and required configurations
- Use varied colors for sticky notes throughout workflow
- Ensure proper node connections reflecting execution order

## Process
Before generating JSON:
1. Analyze the request and break into logical automation steps
2. Choose appropriate nodes for each step
3. Plan proper node connections
4. If request is ambiguous, make best guess using standard automation logic

## n8n Documentation
{{ $json.data }}

**IMPORTANT: Your response must be raw JSON text only. Start typing { immediately and end with } immediately. No markdown formatting whatsoever.**

parameters.content: ## Brain
## Tool

# ðŸ› ï¸ Setup Guide  
**Author:** [Nate Herk](https://www.youtube.com/@nateherk)

Follow the steps below to get this workflow up and running:

### MY RECOMMENDATION
Hook up the chat trigger directly to the workflow builder workflow instead of the "When executed by another workflow" trigger. This will make testing easier and keep everything in one execution. 

If you want to take the multi-agent approach, then follow the below instructions. 

### âœ… Step 1: Connect Your [OpenRouter](https://openrouter.ai/) API Key  
This powers the main LLM agent. Make sure your key is active and added via the HTTP Request or Credential node.

### âœ… Step 2: Add Your [Anthropic](https://console.anthropic.com/dashboard) API Key (Optional)  
If you want to enable thinking using Claude Opus 4, connect your Anthropic API key.

### âœ… Step 3: Link the Developer Tool  
Make sure the node or sub-workflow responsible for building the JSON is properly connected to the main agent. The developer tool should return a structured workflow JSON back to the main flow.

### âœ… Step 4: Add Your n8n API Key  
Create your **n8n API credential** and connect it in the credential section. This is what allows the agent to spin up new workflows automatically in your instance.

### âœ… Step 5: Copy the [Google Doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TiRusVo4DbbANwAr7I0GUGDZY3pmEmHZy3k66mRxLCg/edit?usp=sharing)  
Make a copy in your own Google Suite so you can edit, test, and reference it inside the Google Drive node. Then make sure to connect your Google credentials.

### ðŸ§ª Final Step: Start Testing  
Once all connections are made, start prompting the agent and watch it build n8n workflows on demand.

## Manual Trigger

This workflow starts manually. To process a document, you will need to manually set the Document ID or URL in the 'Set Document ID' node.

## Read Renaming Guidelines

Reads the content of the specified Google Doc. This content will be used by the AI to determine the new document name.

## Read Folder Structure

Reads the data from the specified Google Sheet. This data is expected to contain information about destination folders, likely mapping some document criteria to a folder ID.

## Input Document Simulation

Manually set the Google Drive File ID or URL of the document you want to process in the 'Set Input Document ID' node above.

## Get Input Document Content

Downloads the content of the document specified in the 'Set Input Document ID' node. This content is needed for the AI renaming process.

## Move Document

Moves the renamed document to the destination folder determined in the previous step.

parameters.content:
## Multiple Triggers

**Manual Trigger:** For testing and manual processing

**Google Drive Trigger:** Monitors a specific folder for new documents

**Webhook Trigger:** Receives document upload requests via POST

**Expected webhook payload:**
- `filename`: Original filename
- `content`: Document text content
- `fileId`: (Optional) Google Drive file ID

## Data Normalization

This function handles data from different trigger sources:
- Google Drive: File metadata + needs download
- Webhook: Direct content + metadata
- Manual: Sample data for testing

Outputs normalized format for downstream processing.

## Conditional Download

Checks if file content needs to be downloaded from Google Drive.

**TRUE:** File from Google Drive trigger â†’ Download content
**FALSE:** Content already available â†’ Skip download

## Get Renaming Rules

Reads rules from Google Doc in format:
`[keyword]: new_filename`

Example:
`[invoice]: INVOICE_processed`
`[contract]: CONTRACT_final`

**Configure:**
- Update Document ID
- Set Google Docs credentials

## Get Folder Structure

Reads mapping from Google Sheets:
`Category | Subcategory | Folder Path`

Example:
`Finance | Invoice | /Documents/Finance/Invoices`
`Legal | Contract | /Documents/Legal/Contracts`

**Configure:**
- Update Spreadsheet ID
- Set Google Sheets credentials

## Data Merge

Combines data from:
- Processed file data
- Google Docs (rules)
- Google Sheets (folder structure)

Uses multiplex mode to ensure all data flows to next nodes.

## Apply Renaming Rules

Enhanced JavaScript function that:
1. Extracts file content and metadata from any trigger source
2. Parses rules from Google Doc
3. Matches keywords in document content
4. Determines new filename based on first match
5. Preserves file extension
6. Tracks trigger source for response handling

## Map to Target Folder

Enhanced JavaScript function that:
1. Uses matched keyword from previous step
2. Searches folder structure from Google Sheets
3. Finds corresponding folder path
4. Falls back to default path if no match
5. Preserves trigger source information

## Find Target Folder

Searches Google Drive for the target folder by name.

**Note:** This searches by folder name only. For complex folder paths, you may need additional logic to traverse the folder hierarchy.

## Upload Renamed File

Uploads the processed document to Google Drive:
- Uses the new filename
- Places in the target folder
- Preserves original content
- Works with all trigger sources

**Configure Google Drive credentials**

## Conditional Response

Only sends webhook response if triggered by webhook.

**Webhook Trigger:** Returns JSON response
**Other Triggers:** Workflow completes silently

Response includes:
- Success status
- Original & new filenames
- Target folder path
- Trigger source

parameters.content:
## Google Drive File Management Workflow

This workflow provides comprehensive file management capabilities for Google Drive:

### Key Features:
- **Smart Processing**: Downloads with format conversion
- **Safety First**: Creates backups before modifications
- **Organization**: Moves files to appropriate folders
- **Audit Trail**: Logs all activities

### Workflow Path:
1. MCP Trigger receives request
2. List files or download specific file
3. Create backup if modifying
4. Process based on file type/size
5. Move to organized folders
6. Log all activities

=### Input Parameters

**MCP Trigger accepts:**
- `action`:  download, move, archive
- `fileId`: specific file identifier
- `folderPath`: target folder path
- `filters`: file type, size, date filters

**Example payload:**
```json
{
  "action": "download",
  "fileId": "1a2b3c4d5e6f",
  "convertFormat": "pdf"
}
```

## Error Handling & Safety

**Built-in Safeguards:**
- Backup creation before modifications
- File size and type validation
- Detailed error logging
- Rollback capabilities

**Best Practices:**
- Test with non-critical files first
- Monitor processing logs regularly
- Set up folder permissions properly
- Use version control for important docs

## Performance Optimization

**Recommendations:**
- Use batch operations for multiple files
- Implement rate limiting for API calls
- Cache frequently accessed file metadata
- Set up webhooks for real-time updates

**Monitoring:**
- Track API quota usage
- Monitor workflow execution time
- Set up alerts for failures
- Regular cleanup of old logs

options.systemMessage:
=## V2 System Prompt

You are the Lifestages, Inc. **Document Analysis Agent**, a sophisticated AI assistant responsible for the first stage of document processing: **Analysis and Planning**.

### **Primary Objective**

Your SOLE mission is to analyze an incoming file, consult the knowledge base for existing rules, and formulate a detailed **Execution Plan**. You do **NOT** execute file operations (like moving or renaming). Your only output is a plan that requires human approval.

### **CRITICAL: Knowledge Base Rules**

1.  **Source of Truth:** Your **only** source for rules is the document retrieved via the `KnowledgeBase` tool.
2.  **Strict Adherence:** You must base your plan on the rules found.

### **Available Tools & Usage**

* **`KnowledgeBase`**: Your first step for every file to retrieve the "Naming & Folder Conventions" document.
* **`GDrive_MCP_Client (Read-Only)`**: You can use `Read_File_From_GDrive` to analyze file content and `Search_for_destination_folder` to verify that a proposed folder location already exists. **You are forbidden from using tools that modify files (Move, Rename, Create).**
* **`Request_Approval_from_User`**: This is your final step. You will use this to present your findings and plan to a human for approval.

---

### **Workflow 1: Standard File Plan**

If a file's content clearly matches a rule in the `KnowledgeBase`:

1.  **Analyze Content & Retrieve Policy**: Use `Read_File_From_GDrive` and `KnowledgeBase`.
2.  **Formulate Execution Plan**: Create a precise plan detailing the proposed new filename and the exact destination folder path.
3.  **Verify Destination**: Use `Search_for_destination_folder` to confirm the target folder exists.
4.  **Request Approval**: Send the complete plan for human approval.
    * **Example Message**: *"I have analyzed '[Original_Filename]'. Based on our policies, I propose the following actions:\n\n* **Rename to:** `[Proposed_Filename]`\n* **Move to:** `[Proposed_Folder_Path]`\n\nDo you approve this plan?"*

### **Workflow 2: New Rule Proposal**

If a file does **not** match any existing rule:

1.  **Analyze Content & Retrieve Policy**: Use `Read_File_From_GDrive` and `KnowledgeBase`.
2.  **Identify Anomaly**: Conclude that no specific rule applies.
3.  **Propose New Rule**: Formulate a logical new rule (including format, example, and folder location).
4.  **Request Approval to Update Policy**: Present your findings and the proposed new rule for human approval.
    * **Example Message**: *"I've analyzed 'acme_bill_inv#583.pdf'. It appears to be a vendor invoice, but no specific rule exists. I recommend adding this rule to the knowledge base:\n\n* **Document Type:** VendorInvoice\n* **Format:** `Invoice_[VendorName]_[Invoice#]_[YYYY-MM-DD]`\n* **Folder:** `/04 Finance & Billing/01 Invoices/`\n\n**Do you approve adding this new rule?** Once approved, a new plan will be created to process the original file."*

parameters.content:
## V1 System Prompt ##
You are an expert document management assistant with dual capabilities:

**PRIMARY ROLE: File Processing & Organization**
- Process files that come through the Google Drive trigger
- Apply organizational naming conventions and folder structures
- Use the Policy Knowledge Retrieval tool to reference current policies
- Rename files according to established guidelines
- Move files to appropriate folders based on content and type

**SECONDARY ROLE: Policy Management**
- One-time setup to store organizational policies
- Update policy knowledge base when new policies are available
- Maintain policy references for consistent decision-making

**Decision Logic:**
1. If files are present in the trigger data â†’ Process files
2. If user explicitly requests policy storage â†’ Handle policy management
3. If user asks for help â†’ Provide guidance on available functions

**Tools Available:**
- GDrive MCP Client: Browse, read, rename, and move files in Google Drive
- Policy Knowledge Retrieval: Get current organizational policies
- Policy Knowledge Update: Store new policies (used sparingly)

Always explain your reasoning and cite relevant policies when making file organization decisions.

CRITICAL: You have access to multiple tools, but you must ONLY use tools that are directly relevant to the user's specific request.

POLICY UPDATE REQUESTS: If user asks to "update policies" or "store policies":
- Use the Policy Storage Tool, Gdrive MCP Client for Reading and Searching files and folders ONLY, if needed.
- Do NOT use GDrive MCP Client for any other functions, Google Sheets, or other tools
- Complete the policy storage task and confirm success

FILE PROCESSING REQUESTS: If files need processing:
- Use GDrive MCP Client for file operations
- Use Policy Knowledge Retrieval for naming guidelines
- Use other tools only as specifically needed for file management

Decision Logic:
- If the event source = chat â†’ run Policy Management unless the userâ€™s first message contains the word process-files.

- If the event source = google-drive-trigger â†’ run File Processing & Organisation.

- Never mix both workflows in the same run.

{{ $('Document Data').item.json.data }}

</document>  

Here is the chunk we want to situate within the overall document:
<chunk> 
{{ $json.chunks }}
</chunk>  

Please: 
- Provide a short and succinct <<context>> to situate this chunk within the document for improved search retrieval. 
- Rather than describing numbers, terms, or phrases as provided unless a correction is necessary. 
- If the chunk contains an <<incomplete number, percentage, or entity>>, correct it using the full document. 
- If part of a sentence is cut off, reconstruct the missing words only if necessary for clarity. 
- If the chunk is part of a table, include the complete table entry to preserve data integrity 
- Do not add any additional explanations or formatting beyond the required output. 

Fill in the following format: [succinct context]: [original chunk or corrected version if necessary]  

Your response should contain only the text that replaces these placeholders, without including the placeholders, tags, or these themselves.

options.systemMessage:
=You are an AI Examiner Agent with access to a Supabase database containing exam markschemes via HTTP API. Your primary role is to mark student exam answers fairly, consistently, and accurately according to the official markscheme.

## Core Responsibilities

1. **Mark individual or bulk student answers** against the official markscheme stored in your database
2. **Provide detailed feedback** explaining how marks were awarded or deducted
3. **Maintain consistency** in marking standards across all submissions
4. **Handle various input formats** (single answers, bulk submissions with question numbers)

## Database Access Instructions

- Use HTTP requests to query your Supabase database for markscheme data
- Query markschemes by question number, exam code, or other relevant identifiers
- Always verify you have the correct markscheme before marking any answer

## Marking Process

### For Individual Answers:
1. **Identify the question** from context or ask for question number if unclear
2. **Retrieve the relevant markscheme** from database
3. **Compare student answer** against marking criteria
4. **Award marks** based on markscheme rubric
5. **Provide specific feedback** citing which criteria were met/missed

### For Bulk Submissions:
1. **Parse the submission** to extract question numbers and corresponding answers
2. **Retrieve all relevant markschemes** in batch where possible
3. **Mark each answer systematically**
4. **Provide summary report** with individual question breakdowns
5. **Calculate total score** and percentage if applicable

## Marking Standards

- **Accuracy**: Follow markscheme exactly - do not deviate from official criteria
- **Fairness**: Apply same standards to all students consistently  
- **Partial Credit**: Award partial marks for partially correct answers as specified in markscheme
- **Alternative Answers**: Accept equivalent correct answers not explicitly listed if they demonstrate same understanding
- **Spelling/Grammar**: Only penalize if markscheme specifically addresses language accuracy

## Response Format

### Individual Answer Marking:
```
**Question [X] - [Y] marks available**

**Student Answer Analysis:**
[Brief summary of student's response]

**Marking Breakdown:**
- Criterion 1: [X/Y marks] - [Explanation]
- Criterion 2: [X/Y marks] - [Explanation]
- etc.

**Total Score: [X/Y] marks**

**Feedback:**
[Constructive feedback on strengths and areas for improvement]
```

### Bulk Marking Summary:
```
**Exam Marking Summary**

**Overall Score: [X/Y] marks ([Z]%)**

**Question-by-Question Breakdown:**
Q1: [X/Y] marks - [Brief comment]
Q2: [X/Y] marks - [Brief comment]
[etc.]

**Detailed Analysis:**
[Per question detailed breakdown using individual format above]

**Overall Performance Summary:**
[Strengths, weaknesses, grade indication if applicable]
```

## Error Handling

- If question number is unclear, ask for clarification
- If markscheme cannot be found, request exam details (exam code, subject, etc.)
- If student answer is ambiguous, explain interpretation used for marking
- If database access fails, inform user and request manual markscheme provision

## Key Behaviors

- **Be objective and impartial** in all marking decisions
- **Explain your reasoning** clearly for all mark allocations
- **Be constructive** in feedback while maintaining marking integrity
- **Ask for clarification** when inputs are ambiguous
- **Maintain professional tone** appropriate for educational assessment

## Input Processing

You can handle various input formats:
- Single question: "Q5: [student answer]"
- Multiple questions: "Q1: [answer] Q2: [answer] Q3: [answer]" 
- Formatted submissions with clear question/answer separation

parameters.content:
### Example 1. Publicly Hosted Files
The default way to use Mistral OCR is to give it a public URL of the file you want processed. Great for your own semi-private docs or other people's. If you rather not expose files due to privacy concerns, then you'd want to check out example 2.

### Example 2. Privately Hosted via Mistral Cloud
Give Mistral OCR private and secure access to your files by uploading them to Mistral cloud first. Retrieve the file using a signed URL and pass this to Mistral OCR. Benefit of storing via Mistral could be faster cache access and reduced latency for repeat docs.

## Document Parsing with Mistral OCR
Up your structured document parsing game with Mistral's latest release... **Mistral-OCR**!
* Designed to specifically parse PDF and image files.
* Handles multiple-page documents and images up to 10k pixels.
* Each page is conveniently transcribed as markdown only - there is no plain text output.
* Incredible pricing at only $0.001 per page!

### Requirements
* You'll need a Mistral Cloud API Key
* This template only works with the Mistral Cloud API for Mistral OCR.

### Example 3. No need for Extraction? Talk Directly with the File!
It seems Mistral were also able to integrate OCR capabilities into its text models which allows you to carry out tasks such as document classification and sentiment analysis really quickly. Unfortunately, it doesn't work the same way with images - you have to use Pixtral but the results are really bad!

parameters.content:
## ðŸ¤– AI Email Reply Assistant

## ðŸ”„ What this workflow does
This automation monitors your Gmail inbox, intelligently decides which emails need replies, generates professional responses using AI, and sends them after your approval via Telegram.

---

#### ðŸ§© Node-by-node Breakdown

1. **ðŸ“¥ Trigger: New Email**
   - Gmail Trigger node
   - Polls inbox every minute for new emails

2. **ðŸ“‚ Check: Is Email in Inbox?**
   - Filters emails to only process those in INBOX
   - Skips sent, drafts, and other folders

3. **ðŸ§  AI: Should We Reply?**
   - AI analyzes email content to determine if reply is needed
   - Skips promotions, newsletters, and notifications
   - Only processes emails with questions, requests, or urgent matters

4. **âœ… Check: Response Required?**
   - Routes emails based on AI decision
   - Continues only if reply is needed

5. **âœï¸ AI: Generate Email Reply**
   - Creates professional, contextual email response
   - Maintains appropriate tone and format
   - Generates subject line and body content

6. **ðŸ“± Telegram: Send + Approve**
   - Shows original email and AI-generated response
   - Waits for your approval via Telegram buttons
   - 5-minute timeout for decision

7. **ðŸš€ Send a message**
   - Sends the approved reply via Gmail
   - Only executes if you approve via Telegram

---

#### ðŸ’¡ Key Features
- **Smart Filtering**: Only replies to emails that actually need responses
- **Human Approval**: You control what gets sent
- **Professional Tone**: AI maintains appropriate business communication
- **Mobile Control**: Approve/reject replies directly from Telegram

---

#### ðŸ›  Perfect for:
- Busy professionals managing high email volume
- Customer service representatives
- Sales teams with quick response requirements
- Anyone wanting AI assistance with email management

values.content:
=You are an advanced, unhinged, hilariously entertaining prompt-generation AI specializing in expanding short POV image prompt ideas into detailed, hyper-realistic prompts optimized for Qubico/flux1-dev. Your task is to take a brief input tied to job seeking, job hunting, or resume building and morph it into a cinematic, immersive prompt locked in a first-person perspective, making the viewer feel theyâ€™re living the scene.

NEVER include quotation marks or emojis in your responseâ€”flux API will choke on them, and thatâ€™s a hard no.

The topic of this narrative is: {{ $('Load Google Sheet').item.json.idea }}

The short prompt idea to expand for this image generation is: {{ $json.response.text }}

ONLY GENERATE ONE PROMPT PER IDEAâ€”NO COMBINING. In at least one scene, weave in this environment descriptor: {{ $('Load Google Sheet').first().json.environment_prompt }}, but go wild with unhinged, edgy, funny twists elsewhere (skip the cringe or cheesy garbage). Most job hunting happens on laptops or desktops, so prioritize those over phones. If a phone sneaks in, itâ€™s only showing job-related content like email, LinkedIn, a resume, or a job postingâ€”never a photo or video app.

Every prompt has two parts:

Foreground: Kick off with First person view POV GoPro shot of... and show the viewerâ€™s hands, limbs, or feet locked in a job-related action.

Background: Start with In the background,... and paint the scenery, blending the environment descriptor when required, plus sensory zingers.

Top Rules:

NO quotation marks or emojisâ€”EVER. This is life or death for flux.
Stick to first-person POVâ€”the viewerâ€™s in the driverâ€™s seat, not watching from the sidelines.
Show a limb (hands, feet) doing something job-focusedâ€”typing, holding a resume, adjusting a tie.
Keep it dynamic, like a GoPro clip, with motion and depth mimicking human vision.
If techâ€™s involved (phone, computer), itâ€™s displaying job-hunting goldâ€”email, job boards, resumesâ€”not random trash.
No off-topic actions like recording videos or snapping picsâ€”job hunting only, fam.
Extra Vibes:

Full-body awareness: Drop hints of physical feelsâ€”cramping fingers, racing pulse, slumping shoulders.
Sensory overload: Hit sight, touch, sound, smell, temperature for max realism (coffee whiffs, keyboard clacks).
World grip: Limbs interact with the sceneâ€”tapping keys, handing over papers, stepping up.
Keep it under 1000 characters, one slick sentence, no fluff or formatting.
Make it entertaining, relatable, with an Andrew Tate viral edge for the down-and-out job hustlers.
Examples:

Input: Updating a LinkedIn profile after a long day

Environment_prompt: Tired, cluttered apartment, laptop glow

Output: First person view POV GoPro shot of my hands hammering a laptop, cheeto-dusted fingers aching from the grind, the screen flashing my LinkedIn profile with a fresh connection ping; in the background, a trashed apartment lit by the laptopâ€™s ghostly glow, pizza boxes toppling, traffic humming outside, stale takeout stench hitting my nose as my back screams from the hustle.

Input: Handing over a resume at a job fair

Environment_prompt: Hopeful, busy convention hall, suits everywhere

Output: First person view POV GoPro shot of my hand thrusting out a crisp resume, fingers twitching with nerves as it brushes another palm; in the background, a buzzing convention hall packed with suits, coffee fumes and shoe polish in the air, chatter drowning my pounding heart as I lock eyes with the recruiter.

NO QUOTATION MARKS. NO EMOJIS. EVER.

DO NOT include any quotation marks in your response. Do not put a quote at the beginning or the end of your response.

You are a prompt-generation AI specializing in crafting unhinged, entertaining TikTok captions for a "day in the life" POV story about job hunting or resume writing. Generate five concise, action-driven captions (5-10 words each) that follow a Problem > Action > Reward structure. The first caption should be a shocking or funny hook, and the last should conclude with a satisfying reward. Use emojis sparinglyâ€”only one per caption at most, and only when they add impact; skip them if they donâ€™t enhance the message.

Guidelines:

Perspective: Always first-person POV, immersing the viewer in the story.
Tone: Channel Andrew Tate mixed with Charlie Sheenâ€”cursing and sexual innuendos are fair game.
Content: Focus on job seeking, hunting, or resume building, spotlighting AI as the game-changer.
Narrative: Start with the grind of unemployment or a shitty job, pivot to using AI for resumes and cover letters, and end with scoring the dream gig.
Scenes: Highlight raw, emotional momentsâ€”skip the boring stuff.
Your captions should be wild and entertaining, not polished or professional. The first caption is the hookâ€”make it shocking, hilarious, or ballsy, something Andrew Tate would growl. Use emojis sparinglyâ€”max one per caption, only if it hits harder with it.

Your response should be a list of 5 items separated by "\n" (for example: "item1\nitem2\nitem3\nitem4\nitem5")
={{ $json.idea }}

=You are an unhinged and hilarious TikTok influencer who's like a mix of Andrew Tate and Charlie Sheen. The user is going to provide you with a topic, and then 5 different parts of a story. Your task is to narrate the story as this hilarious character, who isn't afraid to be edgy or curse or use sexual innuendos. However keep each of the 5 talking points brief, as you only have about 5 seconds to speak during each. The entire length of your narration should be around 15 seconds.

Each line item of the users message represents 1 5 second clip, so your response needs to be able to quickly and easily be spoken in those time constraints. Don't say extra things you don't need to. Just quickly tell the story, in order, and make it unhinged, funny, entertaining, and potentially controversially viral. Don't worry about offendeding anyone. Andrew Tate style it.

Do not include any emojis, as your response will be converted from text to speech, so anything but text and punctuation isn't neccesary. Also, don't make your jokes overly corny, speak in a witty, edgy, funny way, but no corny dad jokes or anything cringe.
={{ $('Generate Video Captions').item.json.choices[0].message.content }}

parameters.content: =A new Resume Studio POV video has been created: {{ $json.final_output }}

## 1. ðŸ—¨ï¸Generate video captions from ideas in a Google Sheet

1. Setup your API keys for [PiAPI](https://piapi.ai/?via=n8n), [Eleven Labs](https://try.elevenlabs.io/n8n), and [Creatomate](https://creatomate.com/).
- Once logged in to your Creatomate account, create a new video template and click "source code" in the top right. [Paste this JSON code](https://pastebin.com/c7aMTeLK). This will be your example template for this workflow.
- In your Creatomate template, click the "Use Template" button in the top right and then click "API Integration" and you'll see your template_id. Set this value as your Creatomate Template ID in the Set API Keys node

2. The next node will load a Google Sheet, you can copy the [Google Sheet Template](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1cjd8p_yx-M-3gWLEd5TargtoB35cW-3y66AOTNMQrrM/edit?usp=sharing), simply choose File > Make a copy. Then in the Google Sheets node, connect to your copied sheet template.

3. Next, we generate 5 captions for our video idea with OpenAI. You can edit this node to see the prompt and change it to your needs.

4. In the final two nodes, we use custom javascript code to turn the OpenAI response into a list. Then, it validates to make sure the list was formed correctly (incase of an OpenAI failure to follow instructions)
## DO THIS FIRST

## 2. ðŸ–¼ï¸Generate images with Flux using [PiAPI](https://piapi.ai/?via=n8n) 
### (total cost: $0.0948 approx. as of 3/9/25)
1. OpenAI is used to generate 5 Flux image prompts based on the 5 captions generated. Edit this node to see/edit the prompt instructions. 
2. Next we use some custom javascript to total up how many tokens were used for each 5 generations so we can track our costs later.
3. Then we generate an image with Flux using the [PiAPI service](https://piapi.ai/?via=n8n), waiting to check for failures and retrying if there are any.

You can change the image model used by editing the Generate Image node API call.
Flux models available (as of 3/9/25):
- Qubico/flux1-dev ($0.015) - Currently set
- Qubico/flux1-schnell ($0.0015)
- Qubico/flux1-advanced ($0.02)

For full list of API settings, see the [Flux API Documentation](https://piapi.ai/docs/flux-api/text-to-image?via=n8n)

## 3. ðŸŽ¬Generate videos with Kling using [PiAPI](https://piapi.ai/?via=n8n)
### (total cost: $2.30 approx. as of 3/9/25)
1. We use image-to-video with Kling using [PiAPI](https://piapi.ai/?via=n8n) to generate a video from each image.
2. Then we wait to check for failures, and repeat the generations the failed if there are any.

You can edit the video model used in the Image-to-Video node. For testing, I'd recommend switching from pro to std for lower quality and cheaper price.
Kling models available (as of 3/9/25):
- std (Standard) $0.26 per 5 second video
- pro (Professional) $0.46 per 5 second video - Currently set

For full list of API settings, see the [Kling API Documentation](https://piapi.ai/docs/kling-api/create-task?via=n8n)

## 4. ðŸ”‰Generate voice overs with [Eleven Labs](https://try.elevenlabs.io/n8n)
1. OpenAI API is used to generate a funny script that relates to the captions. Open this node to see/edit the prompt instructions. 
2. Then we use the [Eleven Labs API](https://try.elevenlabs.io/n8n) to generate the voiceover and upload it to our Google Drive so it can be accessed in the next step.

To replace the voice, find the voice ID of the voice you want to use in [Eleven Labs](https://try.elevenlabs.io/n8n), then change the URL in the Generate Voice node to: https://api.elevenlabs.io/v1/text-to-speech/{voice ID here}

For full list of API settings, see the [Eleven Labs API Documentation](https://elevenlabs.io/docs/api-reference/text-to-speech/convert)

## 5. ðŸ“¥Complete video with [Creatomate](https://creatomate.com/)
### (total cost: $0.38 approx. with the Essential plan credits | Free trial credits available)
1. First, the list of videos/captions is combined with the generated voice over into a single item containing all 3 elements.
2. Those are then passed over to the Creatomate Template ID you specified, replacing the template captions/video/audio with your generated ones.
3. When the video is finished rendering, it's then uploaded to Google Drive and the permissions set so it can be accessed with a link.
4. Then we update the original Google Sheet template with the information from our generation, including tokens to calculate cost, then mark this idea as completed.
5. Finally, we send a notification to via [webhook to the Discord server](https://support.discord.com/hc/en-us/articles/228383668-Intro-to-Webhooks) when the video is ready to be downloaded and used!

# ðŸ¤– AI-Powered Short-Form Video Generator with OpenAI, Flux, Kling, and ElevenLabs

## ðŸ“ƒBefore you get started, you'll need:
- [n8n installation](https://n8n.partnerlinks.io/n8nTTVideoGenTemplate) (tested on version 1.81.4)
- [OpenAI API Key](https://platform.openai.com/api-keys) (free trial credits available)
- [PiAPI](https://piapi.ai/?via=n8n) (free trial credits available)
- [Eleven Labs](https://try.elevenlabs.io/n8n) (free account)
- [Creatomate API Key](https://creatomate.com/) (free trial credits available)
- Google Sheets API enabled in [Google Cloud Console](https://console.cloud.google.com/apis/api/sheets.googleapis.com/overview)
- Google Drive API enabled in [Google Cloud Console](https://console.cloud.google.com/apis/api/drive.googleapis.com/overview)
- OAuth 2.0 Client ID and Client Secret from your [Google Cloud Console Credentials](https://console.cloud.google.com/apis/credentials)

parameters.content:
## SETUP REQUIRED
**Author:** [Billy Christi](https://n8n.io/creators/billy/)

**Copy the Google Sheet template here**:  
ðŸ‘‰ [PDF Invoice Parser with Approval Workflow â€“ Google Sheet Template](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ueJfN5dFTXY3_AdvnYUL5_RjV9YwSFvbxwA_ivtqnJk/edit?gid=0#gid=0)

Google Sheets Structure:
Sheet: "Invoices"
â€¢ Column A: Invoice Number  
â€¢ Column B: Invoice Date  
â€¢ Column C: Due Date  
â€¢ Column D: Vendor Name  
â€¢ Column E: Total Amount  
â€¢ Column F: Currency  
â€¢ Column G: Items  
â€¢ Column H: Tax  
â€¢ Column I: Category  
â€¢ Column J: Approved
â€¢ Column K: Approval Notes
â€¢ Column L: Reviewed By

Required Credentials:
â€¢ Google Drive Credential  
â€¢ Gmail Credential 
â€¢ Google Sheets Credential 
â€¢ OpenAI API Key (GPT-4)

## ðŸ§¾ Automated PDF Invoice Processing & Approval Flow using OpenAI and Google Sheets

What This Template Does:

- Monitors **Google Drive**, **Gmail**, and a **web form** for incoming PDF invoices  
- Automatically downloads and extracts raw text from PDF attachments  
- Uses **GPT-4o-mini** to intelligently parse invoice data (invoice number, vendor, date, amount, tax, items, etc.)  
- Categorizes invoices into types such as *Utilities, Travel, Office Supplies, Food & Beverage, Others*  
- Sends a dynamic **approval request email** with an embedded decision form (Yes/No, reviewer name, notes)  
- Stores both approved and rejected invoice data into **Google Sheets** for recordkeeping  
- Sends rejection notifications to the finance team for follow-up  
- Provides a complete, automated approval pipeline with human oversight  
- Includes a structured JSON schema for consistent and error-free AI output  
- Polls input sources every minute to ensure timely and responsive processing  
- Ideal for businesses seeking to **automate their invoice approval and bookkeeping workflows** with AI

## ðŸ“‹ WORKFLOW PROCESS OVERVIEW

1. **Invoice Collection**  
Invoices are captured through three triggers: new PDFs in a Google Drive folder, incoming Gmail messages with PDF attachments, or direct uploads via a web form.

2. **File Handling**  
If uploaded via Drive, the PDF is downloaded using its file ID; if via Gmail or form, the PDF is already available as binary data.

3. **Text Extraction**  
The system extracts raw text from the PDF using the appropriate method based on its source (Drive, Email, or Form).

4. **AI Data Parsing**  
GPT-4 processes the extracted text into structured JSON, identifying invoice details like vendor, date, amount, and categorizing the invoice.

5. **Approval Request**  
An email is sent to the reviewer with an approval form asking for a Yes/No decision along with optional notes.

6. **Decision Routing**  
If approved, the data moves forward for storage; if rejected, a notification is sent to the finance team.

7. **Save Invoice Data**  
All extracted and reviewed invoice data is saved into a Google Sheet, maintaining a full record of each invoice and its status.

parameters.content: ![Kitch on fire](https://media2.giphy.com/media/v1.Y2lkPWVjZjA1ZTQ3ODFuYjVvdWdicXcwOGxqNmZ2anB0c3J2MjB3ZzlhYWtmYzBtejJ2biZlcD12MV9naWZzX3NlYXJjaCZjdD1n/THUvAWoL80rJgwlucA/giphy.webp)

# The "Teleport" Workflow Pattern

This workflow demonstrates a powerful stateful pattern for managing long-running, multi-step processes that need to be paused and resumed by external events.

**Use Cases:**
- Multi-day user onboarding sequences.
- Processes waiting for human approval (e.g., via email link).
- Chatbots that need to maintain conversation state across multiple messages.


It consists of two parts:
1.  **The Main Process (Top):** Your primary business logic. It can be paused at any 'Checkpoint' (`Wait` node).
2.  **The Async Portal (Bottom):** A state-management engine that remembers running processes and can 'teleport' new data to them.

## MAIN PROCESS
### This is your primary business logic. It calls the Portal to register itself, processes some data, and then pauses at a Checkpoint, waiting for another event to resume it.

### 1. Start Main Process

This is the entry point for your stateful process. It could be a webhook, a form submission, or a manual trigger like this one.

### 4. PAUSE at Checkpoint 1

This `Wait` node is a **Checkpoint**. The workflow execution physically stops here and is persisted.

It generates a unique `resume_url` that is stored by the Portal. The only way to wake this execution up is for the Portal to make an HTTP POST request to that specific URL.

### 5. Resumption & Response

When the Portal 'teleports' data, this sequence is triggered.

- **5a:** Receives the new data from the body of the resume request.
- **5b:** Immediately sends a response back to the Portal. This is optional and can be used for passing data back to the Portal if needed.

### 6. PAUSE at Checkpoint 2

This demonstrates that a single Main Process can have multiple, sequential checkpoints. The Portal will always resume the *latest* Checkpoint that was registered for the session.

### 2. Call Async Portal

This is the first and only direct interaction with the Portal. The Main Process sends its `session_id` and its current `resume_url` to register itself.

**Key Setting:** `Wait for Sub-Workflow` is **ON**. The Main Process needs the Portal's response to know if it should continue (new session) or stop (existing session that will get teleported to a checkpoint).

## ASYNC PORTAL
### This is the state-management engine. It's a separate, reusable workflow. Its only job is to check if a session is new or existing. If it's existing, it finds the correct paused workflow's resume url and sends the new data to it. If it's new, then it simply returns all the input items.

### Portal Entry

This is the single entry point for the entire state management system. Any external event (a webhook, a form, another workflow) that needs to interact with a stateful session will call this trigger.

### Session State Manager (Code)

This Code node is the brain of the portal. It uses **Workflow Static Data** (`$getWorkflowStaticData`) as a persistent, shared memory (a "whiteboard") to track all active sessions.

**Technical Breakdown:**
1.  It receives a `session_id` and a `workflow_id`.
2.  It checks its whiteboard to see if an entry for `[workflow_id][session_id]` already exists.
3.  **If it exists (Existing Session):** It retrieves the stored `resume_url` and outputs `new: false`.
4.  **If it's new (New Session):** It stores the incoming `resume_url` and `execution_id` on the whiteboard and outputs `new: true`.

### Route: New vs. Existing Session

This `IF` node directs traffic based on the output of the State Manager.

- **True (Existing Session):** The flow proceeds to the 'Teleport' node to resume the paused process.
- **False (New Session):** The flow proceeds to the 'Pass-through' nodes, which simply return the initial data back to the Main Process so it can start.

### Handle Teleport Error

This is a crucial safety feature. If the 'Teleport' action fails (e.g., the main execution was manually stopped and the `resume_url` is invalid), this branch is triggered.

It allows you to decide whether to stop the session entirely or to reset the state, allowing a new Main Process to begin for that `session_id`.

### TELEPORT: Resume Paused Process

This is the "Teleport" action. It's triggered only for existing sessions.

**Technical Breakdown:**
It takes the `resume_url` retrieved by the State Manager and makes an HTTP POST request to it. This action wakes up the specific `Wait` node that is paused in the Main Process, effectively delivering the new data directly to the correct checkpoint.

## How to Test This Workflow

This pattern requires a special testing method to see it in action.

1.  **Open Two Tabs:** Open this workflow in two separate browser tabs (let's call them **Tab A** and **Tab B**).

2.  **Start the First Session (Tab A):**
    - In **Tab A**, click **"Execute Workflow"** on the `1. Start Main Workflow` node.
    - Observe the execution. It will run until `4. PAUSE at Checkpoint 1` and the status will change to **"Waiting"**. This is your paused process.

3.  **Trigger the Teleport (Tab B):**
    - Now, go to **Tab B** and click **"Execute Workflow"** on the *same* `1. Start Main Workflow` node.

4.  **Observe the Magic:**
    - The execution in **Tab B** will be very short. The Portal will detect an existing session and "teleport" its data.
    - Instantly, the execution in **Tab A** will resume! It will pass Checkpoint 1, run through the `5a` and `5b` nodes, and then pause again at `6. PAUSE at Checkpoint 2`.

5.  **Resume the Final Checkpoint (Tab B again):**
    - In **Tab B**, click **"Execute Workflow"** one more time.

6.  **Observe the Completion:**
    - The execution in **Tab A** will now resume from Checkpoint 2 and run to completion.


This test proves how external events (from Tab B) can control and pass data to a long-running, paused process (in Tab A).

### 2a. Handle Portal's Response

This `IF` node routes the initial execution.

- **False Path (First Run):** When the Portal is first called, it confirms the session is new but sends no special data back. The workflow proceeds down the `false` path to begin its work.

- **True Path (Data from Checkpoint):** If a checkpoint sends data back to the Portal (like Checkpoint 1 does), the Portal returns that data here. This path is for handling data that has been "teleported" from a checkpoint in another execution.

### 3. Process Initial Data

This is a placeholder for your own business logic. This is where you would perform the first set of actions in your process, like creating a user account, sending a welcome email, etc., before reaching the first checkpoint.

### 7. Process Final Data

This represents the final steps of your process after all checkpoints have been passed. For example, this is where you would mark an order as 'complete' or send a final notification.

### Two Types of Checkpoints

This workflow demonstrates two different ways to use `Wait` nodes as checkpoints.

- **Checkpoint 1 (Two-Way):** This `Wait` node has **`Response Mode`** set to `On Resume`. This means it can not only be resumed, but it can also **send data back** to the Portal that resumed it. This is useful for two-way communication.

- **Checkpoint 2 (One-Way):** This `Wait` node has **`Response Mode`** set to `Never`. It can only be resumed; it **cannot send data back**. This is useful for simple, one-way continuation.

options.systemMessage:
=## Role and Primary Objective
You are a customer support AI agent for an online clothing store, specializing in post-sales assistance. Your primary goals are to:
- Help customers track their orders
- Provide information about past and current orders
- Offer clear and concise support

## Communication Guidelines
1. Always be professional, helpful, and precise
2. Use available tools to retrieve accurate information
3. Verify customer identity before sharing order details
4. Protect customer privacy and data confidentiality

## Tool Usage Instructions

### Order Information Retrieval
- Use `get_order` to fetch details for a single order
  - REQUIRED: Complete user information including request, email, and order number
- Use `get_orders` to retrieve multiple orders for a single customer
- Use `get_user` to obtain customer profile information

### Tracking and Support
- Use `get_tracking` to obtain tracking information for an order using the order number
- If a customer cannot find what they need, use `human*assistance`
  - Synthesize the request clearly
  - Include associated user email
  - Provide concise, relevant details

### General Information
- Use `ToS` tool to answer questions about:
  - Terms and Conditions
  - Shipping information
  - General store policies

## Critical Verification Rules
- ALWAYS verify that the email provided matches the order number
- If the email does not match the order:
  - DO NOT provide the correct email
  - Inform the customer that the email address is incorrect
  - Request the correct email associated with the order

## Prohibited Actions
- Never disclose sensitive customer information
- Do not share full order details without proper verification
- Avoid providing speculative or unconfirmed information

## Communication Style
- Be direct and helpful
- Use clear, professional language
- Focus on solving the customer's specific query
- Provide step-by-step guidance when necessary

Today is {{$now}}

parameters.content:
The tracking code request is made through the most popular WooCommerce tracking plugin: "YITH WooCommerce Order & Shipment Tracking". The free version can be [downloaded here](https://wordpress.org/plugins/yith-woocommerce-order-tracking/)
- Create a new workflow and change URL in the node "Http Request" with your WooCommerce shop url

## Post-sale Agent
Get a WooCommerce user's orders and shipping tracking

## General info

Extract information saved in the vector database

To build the RAG system please view [this Workflow](https://n8n.io/workflows/7647-build-a-self-updating-rag-system-with-openai-google-gemini-qdrant-and-google-drive/)

## STEP 1
Create two "API Request" tools in VAPI:
- WooCommerce tool: connect the n8n webhook and set two parameters as the request body: 'email' and 'n_order'
- Rag tool: connect the n8n webhook and set the 'search' parameter as the request body

## STEP 2
- Create a wizard by generating a system prompt that includes the functionality of the two tools created in STEP 1.
- Set the voice in the Voice tab.
- Include the two tools created in STEP 1 in the 'Tools' tab.

## STEP 3
- Create or import a phone number from Twilio, setting it as "Inbound."
- Associate the phone number with the wizard.

## Build AI Voice Assistent with VAPI & Twilio for WooCommerce Post-Sales & RAG
This workflow integrates a **Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system** with a **post-sales AI agent for WooCommerce**. It combines vector-based search (Qdrant + OpenAI embeddings) with LLMs (Google Gemini and GPT-4o-mini) to provide accurate and contextual responses.

Both systems are connected to **VAPI webhooks**, making the workflow usable in a **voice AI assistant** via **Twilio** phone numbers.

The workflow receives JSON payloads from VAPI via webhooks, processes the request through the appropriate chain (Agent or RAG), and sends a structured response back to VAPI to be read out to the user.

name: AI-Powered Document Processing & Organization with Gemini, VLM Run & Google Sheets

parameters.content:
## ðŸ§¾ AI Data Extraction Workflow

**Overview:**
Uploads land in Google Drive â†’ Gemini labels doc type â†’ VLM Run extracts structured fields with OCR and layout parsing â†’ AI Agent maps keys and saves to the right Google Sheet. Change the prompt only to handle any new document type.


**Key Features:**
- ðŸ“ Auto-monitors a Drive folder
- ðŸ”§ VLM Run powered extraction for receipts, resumes, claims, physician orders, blueprints, and any custom type
- ðŸ§  AI Agent reads a single master index sheet to find the target sheet ID by doc type
- ðŸ—‚ï¸ If a sheet has no headers the Agent creates them from the JSON keys then appends values
- ðŸ“ Prompt controls the schema and mapping logic so editing the prompt updates columns and handling


**Perfect for:**
- Expense tracking and audits
- Healthcare and insurance intake
- Resume and HR pipelines
- Construction records and compliance


**Requirements:**
- VLM Run API
- Google Gemini API
- Google Drive and Sheets OAuth2
- n8n AI Agent with prompt that defines types, headers, and key mapping
- A Google Sheet with Columns `Document_Name`, `Spreadsheet_ID` for locating the document storing sheet

## ðŸ“ Input Processing

**Monitors & downloads receipt files from Google Drive.**

**Process:**
1. Watches designated Drive folder
2. Auto-triggers on new uploads
3. Downloads files for AI processing

**Supported Formats:**
- Images (JPG, PNG, WEBP)
- PDF documents
- Mobile camera uploads
- Scanned receipts

## ðŸ¤– VLM Run Execute Agent

**Uses Gemini to detect document type and VLM Run Execute Agent node to extract structured data from images or PDFs.**


**Extracts:**
* Important values according to the document type


**Features:**
* Handles poor quality images
* Supports receipts, resumes, claims, physician orders, construction blueprints, and other generic documents
* OCR text recognition with layout parsing and precision

## ðŸ“Š Data Storage

**Structures and stores extracted data in Google Sheets according to document type automatically.**


**Features:**
- Clean, organized format
- Centralized database for all kind of files
- Auto-appends new entries or headers for any type of document according to the prompt
- Analysis-ready data


**Document Types (can be modified easily by changing the prompt & updating the Sheet which contains the IDs):**
- Resume
- Receipt
- Construction Blueprint
- Physician Order
- Healthcare Claims
